title: The Assassin update is a failure.
body:
To understand why its a failure, its important to understand why riot wanted to update assassins in the first place.

Riot: We want the opponent to have windows of opportunity when fighting an assassin. We don't want an assassin to unload all of their damage all at once onto a target.

Meanwhile {{champion:1}}{{champion:161}} {{champion:45}} {{champion:92}} {{champion:99}} {{champion:63}} and even a damn full AP {{champion:54}} does EXACTLY that.

So why would I pick any of the assassins when burst mages pretty much do exactly what assassins were reworked into not doing? Surely you guys have to see how flawed this is right? {{champion:1}} just presses a bunch of buttons and deletes an carry in .5 seconds where as a kat or LB takes 2.5 seconds just to set up their combos.

replies.body: the difference is burst mages are incredibly immobile in comparison.

> [{quoted}](name=dynikus,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=hxAfYwor,comment-id=0001,timestamp=2016-11-14T05:35:21.872+0000)
>
> the difference is burst mages are incredibly immobile in comparison.

{{summoner:4}} {{summoner:6}}

Both of these summoner spells are massively overpowered, people are used to flash being overpowered at this point but ghost definitely puts a lot of champions over the edge. Still his point is correct, burstmages are far less mobile than assassin, there's not even a comparison here, the average number of dashes or blinks on an assassin's kit is somewhere around 2, the total number of dash abilities on burst mages kits is two, Liss E and Ahri R.

The difference is burst mages need to set up in order to 100-0 you.   Typically have to hit their cc and are plagued with a lack of mobility.

Assassins don't need to set up as simply being near you will suffice to start them and because they have mobility (and thus can engage from a much greater range) they need to have counterplay after they jump on you or else it isn't fair.
